General course objectives:
General course objectives
This course aims at providing a solid foundation in epidemiological modeling. Students will learn a wide array of techniques that can be used to analyze outbreaks and forecast the development of epidemics. The course will focus on the mathematical aspects of disease modeling and the python programming language will be used extensively.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Recognize the terms in the SIR model and its derivatives
Adapt a basic model to describe a given epidemic
Choose a proper model framework given a type of outbreak
Solve a time-dependent epidemiological model numerically
Fit model parameters to epidemiological data
Explain the effect of noise in epidemiological data
Explain the effects of seasonality and other driving terms
Obtain the endemic equilibrium for a given model
Calculate the propagation speed of an epidemic using a spatial model
Analyze an epidemic using lattice based models
Content: Dynamical systems, analysis of stability and fixed points, non-linear dynamics and chaos. Temporal models (SIR and derivatives). Risk structures. Multi-host/multi-pathogen models. Forced models. Random dynamics and noisy models, agent-based models. Spatial models, lattice-based models and meta-populations. Disease control and prevention. Global mobility, pandemics, economic epidemiology, and antimicrobial resistance.
Course literature: "Modeling Infectious Disease in Humans and Animals", Keeling and Rohani, Princeton Press
